Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based solely on a video showing a crocodile being pulled by a rope on a flooded street. There is no additional evidence or information provided to verify the claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the video shows a crocodile roaming the street in Pakistan in August 2020. However, there is no direct evidence or confirmation of the location and time of the video.
Exist alternative explanation: The video description from the Indian newspaper Times of India suggests that similar incidents of crocodiles entering housing complexes were recorded in Vadodara, India, due to heavy rains. This alternative explanation raises doubts about the claim's accuracy.
Contradict fact: The state-run Sindh Wildlife Department in Karachi denied the claims made in the video, stating that the news of the escape of a sacred crocodile from the shrine of Manghopir was baseless. This contradicts the claim made in the video.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as it relies on a single video and its Urdu caption, without providing additional context or information to support its validity.
Understate: There is no evidence of the claim understating any information or facts.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence of the claim exaggerating any information or facts.
